metadata.title: Commentary: Digital language and learning in the time of coronavirus

abstract.text: during the time of the COVID-19 pandemic. This special issue on 'Digital language practices: Media, awareness, pedagogy' is therefore particularly timely when most of the world has to suddenly switch on digitally. The research reported in these studies is a tour de force in which researchers start their queries from the digital spaces they are interested in. Each study in this collection highlights how everything is done differently digitallypeople read, write and communicate differently online, and organisations need to respond differently online. The studies in this collection show that the young people in the studies understand that perfectly and have adapted according. The collection of papers certainly speaks to the core national, social and economic issues we have faced in the last four months. This may sound intuitive, but our COVID-19 experiences teach us that digital adaptation is almost a best-kept secret. We have learned that we are not prepared for a global-scale epidemic, not medically, not mentally, and not economically. What we have also learned is that although technology is more important than ever, we have not taken people's digital practices as seriously as we should. Coronavirus (mis)information is spreading faster than the virus, and there is no stopping conspiracy theories and 'miracle cures' being populated online. Their reproduction numbers are higher than 1. With the first cases recorded in China, the rise of racism and xenophobia is not limited to the street as incidences of online attacks have also risen. Government surveillance, through contact tracking apps, for instance, begs for a new public understanding of algorithms. While governments around the world are trying to tell the stories of coronavirus for public consumption, whether it is about the use of 'war metaphors' (e.g. in the UK) or the language of science (e.g. in Germany), they are not necessarily giving out the stories in languages other than the dominant national language. Companies also are having a difficult time with storytellinghow to move from chanting 'we're all in this together' to selling new cars or bigger TVs now? Media and governments have trouble with learning at a distance as schools are temporarily switched to online delivery. Online learning became 'homeschooling' with various ministers saying students have 'lost' education rather than being educated differently.

Technology has been adopted without giving too much consideration to young people's digital practices. However, morning TV shows are constantly showing glimpses of these discarded practicesthe latest TikTok challenge, a viral tweet, or a YouTube sensation -as 'positive' or 'uplifting' stories.
It is a strange time for our generations who have not seen anything like this before.

Technically this is not true. Both authors experienced the SARS epidemic in Hong Kong in 2003. Rumors and misinformation about a 'flu-like' pneumonia were circulating on ICQ and MSN and through text messages, and news reported that people were panic buying vinegar and salt. By late March 2003, all schools were closed, and learning by distance and online was enforced. The school closure lasted for about a month but all families were expected to be able to homeschool their children via online resources provided by schools and teachers from their e-classes. This was certainly a turning point for those families that could afford Internet connection services and devices to become more connected and take an interest in digitization of education.

Trucano (2014) discussed the transformational effects of pandemic outbreaks on everyday education, calling them 'black swan' events. But many more students also 'lost' one month of education because there was not enough home support or resources to sustain online learning. It was also an era before video conferencing with teachers using telephone and text messaging to ensure student learning.

The scenarios above now sound familiar to Australians and many others in 2020. Many Australians with families and friends in Asia had heard about the Wuhan Pneumonia (before it was renamed Coronavirus) in late 2019 and early 2020, and learned about lockdown and school closure in China, Hong Kong and Taiwan. Information was circulated on various social media platforms, especially on Chinese-language platforms. Many Australians also learned from their families and friends about how they have been dealing with school closure and education disruptions, the woes of online distance learning, working from home and self isolation. Australia soon went into lockdown in late March, just like many other parts of the world, and immediately people's communication patterns changed. Even though schools have remained open, parents

were not sending their children to school. In-person school attendance dropped to about 5 per cent. To cope with demands of students learning from home, teachers immediately prepared transitioning to an online delivery mode. State education departments adopted a laissez faire approach to the definition of 'online learning'. Some secondary schools required video conferencing during formal school hours (e.g. 9 am to 2 pm). Some primary schools distributed digital learning packages with one roll call every morning.

There are guidelines for learning digitally and remotely, but state governments have not enforced any preferred routines. Though officially open, schools were effectively closed since the end of March, and students were impacted in various ways. When each school and teacher could decide on the best learning digital delivery, parents are learning new skills on how their children are learning online. However, the education sector has largely taken it for granted that students from primary to tertiary and regardless of their age can naturally transition from a predominantly face-to-face to online teaching and learning mode without much trouble. This assumption is based on a simple view of technology use and practicesas long as a digital device and Internet connection is available, one can learn. This is the dominant media ideology about 'tech savvy' young people who navigate the digital worlds with grace and ease (See Tagg & Seargeant; Georgakopoulou, this issue). There is also an assumption that schools and teachers would be able to switch seamlessly between the two content delivery modes. In fact, many teachers have been asked to do both face-to-face and online teaching as some students are still attending schools. Meanwhile, family members are expected to align their daily schedules to support their children's learning.

The newly enforced online learning also has very little regard for students' existing digital practices. There is frequently an assumption of two separate digital worldsplatforms and websites separated by functionalityone for play and one for school. In terms of platforms and applications, digital communication is a very rapidly changing field. Schools and teachers are using (presumably) safely secured learning management systems (LMS) like Moodle and Google Suite. These are the 'formal study' spaces in which students are expected to behave, respond and interact as if they were in the physical space of the school. Many classrooms are simply being recreated spatially online using video conferencing tools and apps without consideration being given to patterns of online interaction and everyday digital practices. For instance, students are directed to watch YouTube videos while teachers are streaming them during video conferencing sessions. Some school teachers upload homework so students can print out to do them and then submit a photo as proof of completion. Universities are running three-hour Zoom lectures with lecturers as the talking heads. During the COVID19 strange time, we are not seeing Second Life classrooms being promoted. This could be attributed to a general lack of interest in the school sector, as opposed to the higher education and informal education sectors (Chen, 2016) . We are equally puzzled by how texting was not used more efficiently to keep online learning less expensive and more accessible for families with limited data plans or no laptops or tablets. The school-based online learning is also primarily text-based with a lot less consideration for the visual mode of communication. Schools have not caught on to Instagram and they certainly have not considered TikTok. Now that schools are online, literacy practices are still being taught according to the genre theory of the late 1990s. The assumed mode of communication in school-based online learning is still heavily text-biased. Visual social media is not seriously being considered as part of young people's everyday digital practices and literacy (Dovchin, 2020) . Hashtags are viewed as a symbol for the Mathematics lesson but not a metadata tag for writing and composing on social networking websites and apps.

We do not want to argue that teachers and schools need to follow every social media fad to catch up with their students. But young people's out-of-class digital practices have fundamentally changed how we read and write. Androutsopoulos and Busch (this issue) demonstrate clearly that punctuation is viewed, understood, and used differently when young people text. In their study, young text message senders reflect critically on the use of punctuation signs because they understand that texting, as digital communication, demands different grammatical and pragmatic rules. When will hash tags be taught as an essential component of writing, as important as paragraphing and the use of full stops?

We haven't even started the discussion of incorporating emojis in classroom reading and writing (Danesi, 2017; Seargeant, 2019) . Can we now use emojis to teach adjectives, nouns, metaphors, vocabulary and grammatical structure? Teachers may not yet believe in the benefits of incorporating emojis for literacy practices, but researchers of Arrernte, a Central Australian language, developed a bilingual English and Arrernte emoji app to encourage language learning uptake (ABC News, 29 Nov 2019). The app turns Arrernte cultural symbols and language into 90 emojis, with each emoji represented in both English and its Arrernte translation. The main reason for developing a language learning app through emoji is obvious to the researcher, Joel Liddle:

We should be writing text messages and writing essays for school in Arrernte and we should be utilising Arrernte emojis, because if we utilise them in the digital realm then it means that they're used daily still.

Yet this point about incorporating everyday digital practices in learning is less than apparent for many. While there is an emerging discussion on whether online learning inevitably disadvantages children from lower socio-economic and migrant backgrounds, these arguments have been used, in Australian contexts, as a weapon in federation and state politics about school reopening. There was virtually no discussion on how online learning may be developed and delivered to align with young people's existing digital practices. Young people are expected to accommodate while trying to learn during challenging times.

When social distancing and home isolation are advocated as the most effective national measures for preventing infection, governments around the world promote the use of digital tools to connect with families and friends. Morning news programmes teach people how to use freely available video conferencing tools for personal and work purposes. Zoom, the video conferencing tool, reported that 200 million people used the tool every day in March 2020 (CNBC, April 14, 2020). With video conferencing sessions held for both personal and professional purposes, we are seeing our colleagues' and students' home deco (especially ceilings), pets and families, and more disturbingly, their choices of virtual backgrounds. We are sharing more than we would normally do in our regular daily interactions. We are obliged to share our bakes to show that we haven't gone insane. We are also now obliged to join office WhatsApp groups to keep these 'corridor chats' online. The new digital buzzwords include 'digital wellbeing' while working hours seep into evenings and weekends because we have nowhere else to go. And there are increasing reports of 'Zoom fatigue' as people are finding it more taxing to use video conferencing tools (Harvard Business Review, 29 April 2020).
body_text.section: How does the government view learning digitally?

body_text.text: Sindoni (this issue) demonstrates that mode-switching in video interactions is a lot more complex and complicated than anticipated and noticed. This is evidenced in the challenges students in her study faced when trying to transcribe short video-mediated interactions.
body_text.section: How does the government view learning digitally?

body_text.text: In the mass media, the complexity of online interactions and navigation is frequently being minimized in order to promote university up-skilling and more formal qualifications. The Australian Education Minister, Dan Tehan, told everyone 'rather than bingeing on Netflix, binge on studying' (Brinsden, Apr 12, 2020) . There are 'good' digital activities, and there are 'bad' digital activities. Bingeing on Netflix is inherently bad, even though many foreign language teachers swear by various popular Netflix series as learning resources. There is even a Chrome extension, 'Language Learning with Netflix' (2020) to assist language learning. And how about the popularity of 'La Casa de Papel' reintroducing an Italian folk song, 'Bella Ciao' as the new symbol of resistance and a chart topper around the world? (Fernandez, 2020) . This response is not isolated in thinking everyone is doing nothing during the COVID19 shutdown. It appears that the Australian government is also not treating online learning as one way of content delivery, when the Prime Minister and Education Minister say that students are losing education by learning online at home and not in school (Sky News, 18 March, 2020; ABC News, 15 April 2020) . It is fair to argue that online delivery of school does not necessarily suit every child due to structural social and economic inequality of the families to access technology. However, it is unfair to say that students who are learning online are not getting educated at all. This shows a certain prejudice of our governments in conceptualising learning and digital practices. Even in the best of formal education contexts, digital practices are being viewed as the lesser half of the equation.
body_text.section: How does the government view learning digitally?

body_text.text: One of the less considered aspects of language learning in the digital world is translanguaging in literacy practice. While English (or the respective national languages in other countries) is predominately the only language used for education during the COVID19 disruption, as many schools (and including universities) immediately mobilised human resources for online transitioning rather than for language support, multilingualism seems to have disappeared. The focus on English (at least in the Australian context) in digital communication from governments and schools blindsided the multilingual repertoires of the students and their families. Though international students in many English-speaking countries are making a significant contribution to national income (AUD37.6 billions in 2018 -19 to the Australian economy), the consideration for their multilingual funds of knowledge is even more important.
body_text.section: How does the government view learning digitally?

body_text.text: Translanguaging is the norm, rather than then the exception (Sultana and Dovchin, this issue). Students are bringing their out-of-class critical awareness of the world into their everyday interactions. International students are also demonstrating that they are very vulnerable during this time with limited access to part-time employment and travel restrictions. Many economists predict that study abroad as we know will not be the same (Bloom, 21 May 2020). We are certainly looking at a situation where international study is going to be virtual, or blended for a shorter stay for cost saving (Durden, 4 June 2020) . While Durden is speaking from the perspectives of American universities with the premises that courses are taught in English, he argues that a digital delivery of study abroad means thinking beyond currently modes of education. How we market and provide education internationally needs to incorporate basic understandings of how people communicate digitally, and translanguaging is a given. And this emphasis on digital delivery will also mean a new exploration of mode-switching which could mean a greater degree of clarity in meaning-making and understanding in online teaching and learning (Sindoni, this issue).
body_text.section: How does the government view learning digitally?

body_text.text: Something similar could be said of contexts for digital communication. One of the main developments in the Internet over the past decade or so has been the shift from fixed networks to satellite-based mobile networks (e.g. to smart phones and tablets), which has had a significant impact on the spatiality of digital communication, especially where and when people communicate digitally.
body_text.section: Coronavirus safety: Surveillance, (mis)information and official storytelling

body_text.text: In the contexts of living in the age of coronavirus, the more concerning is the governmental push of COVID contact tracking apps: including Australia (COVIDSafe), China (a combined use of QR codes and other credit tracking strategies), South Korea (location data, CCTV and credit card transaction data), Taiwan, Germany, Israel (The Shield), and Hong Kong (a hand band). There are also a number of countries rolling out similar contact tracking apps, for instance, the United Kingdom (to roll out in mid-May), France, Austria and Switzerland, and Russia. In the case of Australia, the tracking app COVIDSafe was released before the Privacy Amendment (Public Health Contact Information) Bill 2020 was passed. Everyone was pressed to download the app to the extent that the Prime Minister floated the idea that 'the first step back to the pub would be downloading the app' (Coughlan, 2 May, 2020) . There was only limited discussion of the possible privacy or surveillance issues. More than 5.1 million people in Australia have downloaded the app while the government and the app developer are still ironing out privacy issues. WESNET, a watchdog organisation, advises domestic abuse victims leaving phones with the downloaded app behind for any confidential support meetings. The number of uptake is lower than anticipated when there are an estimate of 16 million adult mobile phone users in Australia. This hesitation has been linked to mobile phone users' perceptions of the security used by the app, and the management of user data (Koslowski, 27 April 2020). Jones' (this issue) discussion of young university students' metaphors for understanding how algorithms work can be further narrowed as 'authority' and 'adversary' in the cases of contact tracking apps or digital measures. Though most people will only have a layman understanding of algorithms of digital tools and most are not actively aware of their pervasiveness on popular websites and tools (e.g. Google, Facebook…), official and media pressure to download the COVIDSafe app made questions of digital privacy a matter of public debate.
body_text.section: Coronavirus safety: Surveillance, (mis)information and official storytelling

body_text.text: There is also current discussion and concern about the public understanding of online dissemination of information. COVID-19 sees new waves of misinformation being spread online, and the World Health Organisation has had to release a series of multilingual myth-busting posters (e.g. 5G mobile networks do not spread the virus).
body_text.section: Coronavirus safety: Surveillance, (mis)information and official storytelling

body_text.text: The spread of misinformation is more complex and faster than the spread of the virus itself. Tagg & Seargeant (this issue) argue that governments need to take account of 'people's evolving language/media awareness' and how these experiences in turn shape users' online experiences and practices. COVID-19 has shown us that 'fake news' and (mis)information can be spread unintentionally, and during challenging times, they are consumed much faster in response to fear.
body_text.section: Coronavirus safety: Surveillance, (mis)information and official storytelling

body_text.text: An interpersonal approach to examine information spread is a study of official storytelling as well. People reacted strongly to the presumed British Government's initial floating of a 'herd immunity' strategy. Americans were told that coronavirus infection was just like flu, and then the death rate in the US told a different story. In the early days, governments were not able to effectively use the mass media and digital media to give a coherent COVID-19 story (Bremmer, 12 Jun 2020; Dewan, Pettersson & Croker, 16 Apr 2020) . What is the story? Georgakopoulou's (this issue) analyses of marketing rhetoric and story-making on social media demonstrate that corporate stories have to conform to set template and algorithms. Governments, politicians, and scientists could not agree on one Coronavirus story because it is so new. Some governments use scientific language and some resort to war metaphors to create a response scenario (Musu, 8 Apr, 2020) . Is social isolation the only preventative measure? The global lockdown triggered the onset of mass unemployment and economic recession around the world. On traditional and digital media, companies are desperate to curate new storytelling of 'we are all in this together', and then 10 seconds later, just buy 'product X, Y and Z'. We have yet to brand COVID-19, and there is as yet not a coherent story of battling or recovering from this pandemic. There is no playbook, but there are algorithms. provide a new critical lens that could be applied to other applications and platforms, such as Instagram, Snapchat, TikTok, the use of 'groups' in messaging apps, online shopping and reviewing, the use of online tools in campaigns and protests, memes as political/subversive tools, talking robots, augmented and virtual realities, fake news, online dating, gambling and porn (and the increasing 'normalisation' of both practices), bullying and image-based abuses in social media…etc. All these are linked to (young) people's everyday digital practices, and yet a pandemic shows us that the digital divide is not just about age or digital fluency, but it is the incorporation of digital literacy and practices in existing formal structure.
body_text.section: Coronavirus safety: Surveillance, (mis)information and official storytelling

FIGREF1.text: The papers in this special issue open up new possibilities for research on digital practices. The studies show us to look beyond the English-only domains (Sultana & Dovchin) and the traditional grammar (Androutsopoulos & Busch) into different critical interfaces to understanding algorithms (Jones), multimodal interaction (Sindoni), information (Tagg & Seargeant), and corporate identity (Georgakopoulou). The papers
